componenttext:
Greetings, and welcome to the EQT Corporation Year-End Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] And as a reminder, this conference is being recorded.
I would now like to turn the conference over to Patrick Kane. Thank you. You may begin.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brenda. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for participating in EQT Corporation's conference call. With me today are Dave Porges, Chief Executive Officer; Steve Schlotterbeck, President of EQT and President of Exploration and Production; Robe
componenttext:
Thanks, Brenda. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for participating in EQT Corporation's conference call. 
With me today are Dave Porges, Chief Executive Officer; Steve Schlotterbeck, President of EQT and President of Exploration and Production; Robert McNally, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Lisa Hyland, Executive Vice President of Midstream.
This call will be replayed for a 7-day period beginning at approximately 1:30 Eastern Time today. The telephone number for the replay is (201) 612-7415 with the confirmation code of 13637701. The call will also be replayed for 7 days on our website. 
To remind you, the results of EQT Midstream Partners, ticker EQM; and EQT GP Holdings, ticker EQGP, are consolidated in EQT's results. Earlier this morning, there was a separate joint press release issued by EQM and EQGP. The partnerships will have a joint earnings conference call at 11:30 a.m. today, which requires that we take the last question of this call at 11:20. The dial-in number for that call is (201) 689-7817.
In a moment, Rob will summarize EQT's year-end 2016 results, and Steve will give a brief operational update. Following the prepared remarks, Dave, Steve, Rob and Lisa will all be available to answer your questions.
First, I have one administrative note. As a result of the asset drop-downs into EQM, we changed our reporting format for the midstream business unit. We now report gathering results and transmission results separately, which aligns with EQM's reporting. The midstream assets that were not dropped into EQM are now rolled into the EQT production's results. For your use, we have posted on our website the Q4 and full year 2016 results using the old format as well as the 2016 quarterly results using the new format.
I'd like to remind you that today's call may contain forward-looking statements. You can find factors that could cause the company's actual results to differ materially from these forward-looking statements listed in today's press release and under Risk Factors in EQT's Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2015, as updated by any subsequent Form 10-Qs, which are on file at the SEC and available on our website; and under Risk Factors in EQT's Form 10-K for year ended December 31, 2016, which will be filed with the SEC next week.
Today's call may also contain certain non-GAAP financial measures. Please refer to this morning's press release for important disclosures regarding such measures, including reconciliations to the most comparable GAAP financial measures.
I'd now like to turn the call over to Rob McNally.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Pat. Good morning, everyone. As you read in the press release this morning, EQT announced 2016 adjusted loss of $0.33 per diluted share compared to 75% -- $0.75 adjusted earnings per diluted share in 2015. Adjusted operating cash flow attributable
componenttext:
Thanks, Pat. Good morning, everyone. As you read in the press release this morning, EQT announced 2016 adjusted loss of $0.33 per diluted share compared to 75% -- $0.75 adjusted earnings per diluted share in 2015. Adjusted operating cash flow attributable to EQT was $816 million in 2016 compared to $825 million in 2015.
The high-level story for the year was very strong volume growth in a lower commodity price environment. As a reminder, EQT Midstream Partners and EQT GP Holdings results are consolidated in EQT's corporate's results. EQT recorded $322 million of net income attributable to noncontrolling interest in 2016 and $83 million in the fourth quarter of 2016. Notably, 2016 production volumes were 26% higher than last year and gathering volumes were up by 21%. Due to the lower commodity prices, adjusted EPS and adjusted operating cash flow were both down versus 2015, although results in both used [ph] were impacted by some unusual items that should be considered when interpreting and comparing the results year-over-year. 
Now looking at the fourth quarter. Adjusted EPS was $0.25 per diluted share. That compares to adjusted loss per share of $0.07 in the fourth quarter of 2015. Adjusted operating cash flow attributable to EQT was $327 million in the fourth quarter compared to $239 million for the fourth quarter of 2015. Production sales volume was 28% higher than the fourth quarter of 2015 while commodity prices were slightly lower. During the quarter, we realized better-than-expected average differential due to a colder December. 
In the fourth quarter, EQT completed the final drop of midstream assets to EQT Midstream Partners for $275 million. The drop included Allegheny Valley Connector, transmission and storage system, along with several Marcellus gathering systems. The sale did not include a small gathering system, which were sold in a separate transaction for $75 million, resulting in total proceeds of $350 million from the transactions.
Now I'll move on to a brief discussion of results by business segment. I will limit my discussion to the full year results as explanations for the full year for the most part applies to the fourth quarter as well.
Starting with the production result. EQT Production achieved record production sales volume of 759 Bcfe for 2016, again, representing a 26% increase over 2015. As has been the case for many years now, the story in 2016 at EQT Production was strong production growth driven by production from our Marcellus shale wells. 2016 was our [ph] seventh straight year of more than 25% sales volume growth. However, lower average realized price has more than offset the increased production in our financial results. The average realized price, including cash settled derivatives, was $2.47 per Mcf for 2016, which was $0.62 or 20% lower than last year. For the full year, total operating expenses at EQT Production were $2.1 billion or 6% higher year-over-year. DD&A, gathering, transmission, processing and SG&A were all higher, again consistent with the significant production growth. Per unit LOE, including production taxes, were 21% lower for the year as volume increased more than expenses. 
Now moving on to the Midstream results. EQT gathering operating income was $289 million, up 19% year-over-year, mainly as a result of increased gathering revenues, partly offset by increased operating expenses. Total operating expenses were $109 million or $17 million higher than 2015.
Looking at EQT transmission. Operating income was $238 million, 12% higher than 2015. Operating revenues were $40 million higher than 2015, primarily due to affiliate contracting for additional capacity under firm contracts primarily on the Ohio Valley Connector, which was placed into service on October 1, 2016. Operating expenses were $100 million or $10 million higher than in 2015.
And finally, our standard liquidity update. We closed the year in a great liquidity position with 0 net short-term debt outstanding under EQT's $1.5 billion unsecured revolver and about $1.4 billion of cash and marketable securities on the balance sheet, excluding EQM. We currently forecast $1.3 billion of operating cash flow for 2017 at EQT, which includes approximately $200 million of distributions to EQT from EQGP. So we're fully capable of funding our roughly $1.5 billion of 2017 CapEx, which excludes EQM and EQGP with operating cash flow as well as current cash on hand.
So with that, I will turn the call over to Steve.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rob. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. As we announced in early December, we're planning to invest $1.5 billion in 2017, including $1.3 billion for well development. Our 2017 sales volume guidance is between 810 and 830 Bcfe wi
componenttext:
Thanks, Rob. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. As we announced in early December, we're planning to invest $1.5 billion in 2017, including $1.3 billion for well development. Our 2017 sales volume guidance is between 810 and 830 Bcfe with a 2017 growth coming primarily from completing wells which were spudded in 2016. Our 2017 activity will result in 15% to 20% growth in 2018, and we expect to grow in the 15% to 20% range for at least the next several years.
Moving on to year-end reserves. Our 2016 year-end total proved reserves increased 35% to 13.5 Tcfe versus year-end 2015. This increase was driven by our 2016 acquisition activity and our drilling efforts, which continue to expand the boundaries of our core Marcellus and Upper Devonian development areas. Acquisitions added approximately 2.4 Tcfe, 2.1 of which is associated with PUD reserves that we will be developing over the next 5 years. Drilling activity resulted in 2.4 Tcfe of extensions, discoveries and other additions. Excluding the impact of acquisitions, we replaced 246% of our 2016 production. With the acquisitions factored in, we replaced 555% of our 2016 production. 
Consistent with our consolidation strategy, the average lateral length of our PUDs is more than 600 feet longer than those booked in 2015. It's also worth noting that our 2.4 Tcfe of acquired proved reserves is only associated with the reserves directly associated with that new acreage. Over 600 Bcfe of this year's proved reserves resulted from the synergies created from our leasing and acquisition activity. These synergies allowed the lengthening of laterals on our existing acreage and are a key driver of our consolidation strategy that not only adds proved reserves, it also dramatically improves the economics of our existing development opportunities. 
We continue to focus on operational efficiencies, and the combination of longer laterals and technical improvements has decreased our per unit development costs year-over-year. Our development cost for Marcellus wells completed in 2016 was $0.72 per Mcfe, 10% lower than the $0.80 per Mcfe for last year's Marcellus wells. Compared to last year, total probable and possible reserves are 2.1 Tcf lower due to a 7.2 Tcf reduction in the Huron. However, Marcellus and Upper Devonian probable and possible reserves are up 5.3 Tcfe or 83% from 2015.
Regarding our total resource potential figures. It should come as no surprise that our acquisition helped increase our estimates significantly, but I do want to emphasize that our Utica estimates still only reflect the 30 Tcfe associated with what we believe is in the core. Additionally, the only proved Utica reserve booked this year are from the 5 producing wells, which still have approximately 39 Bcfe of net remaining reserves. We have not yet booked any proved, undeveloped, probable or possible reserves in the Utica.
The questions on investors' minds most recently have been on the status of MVP, the Utica and consolidation. I'll briefly update you on these 3 topics. There's not much update on MVP. Last September, we received a FERC draft Environmental Impact Statement, and the comment period on the draft EIS ended in late December. We are currently preparing responses to a FERC environmental information request, which is typical for the process as the commission works to develop the final EIS. We continue to target a late 2018 in-service date.
On the Utica, since last quarter, we have not turned any new wells online. We are currently fracking the BIG-177 in West Virginia and we're also currently drilling another well in Greene County, Pennsylvania. We plan on spudding 7 Utica test wells during 2017.
On consolidation, as I mentioned last quarter, we had a 230,000 net core Marcellus acres from 2013 to 2016. We believe the biggest benefit from continued consolidation is the economic benefits of longer laterals. We will continue to look to add acreage that bolts on or fills in our existing core acreage position. This week, we purchased an additional 14,000 core West Virginia acres, primarily in Marion and Monongalia Counties, West Virginia for $130 million. Consistent with our objective of extending laterals, this acquisition will allow us to extend 64 well locations from an average of 1,900 feet to 5,700 feet. The latest deal is consistent with our previous comments on consolidation. One, we are focused in our core motivated by longer laterals; and two, small deals are more likely than large acreage deals for corporate transactions.
Our focus continues to be increasing shareholder value by focusing on full-cycle returns. We will accomplish this by driving development and operating costs lower, expanding optionality in our sales portfolio to improve our realized prices and maintaining a strong balance sheet in order to weather the inevitable commodity price cycles.
With that, I'll turn the call back to Pat Kane.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve. This concludes the comments portion of the call. Brenda, can we please open the call for questions?
componenttext: Thank you, Steve. This concludes the comments portion of the call. Brenda, can we please open the call for questions?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Drew Venker with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Drew Venker with Morgan Stanley.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: I thought maybe we could just start by -- Steve, if you had any more thoughts on the focus of your role as you take over the helm. And if you can just talk more about shifting to more operations-related strategy than financially related strategy, if you h
componenttext: I thought maybe we could just start by -- Steve, if you had any more thoughts on the focus of your role as you take over the helm. And if you can just talk more about shifting to more operations-related strategy than financially related strategy, if you have any thoughts there?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks, Drew. I think just maybe just a couple general comments in that area. I've been here for 17 years now, so I've been working either for or with Dave for that entire time. So I've been involved and certainly onboard with the strategy and the d
componenttext: Well, thanks, Drew. I think just maybe just a couple general comments in that area. I've been here for 17 years now, so I've been working either for or with Dave for that entire time. So I've been involved and certainly onboard with the strategy and the direction of the company. So I think you shouldn't expect to see dramatic strategic changes in what we're trying to accomplish. More likely, you'll see changes in how we or how -- differences in how we function, between Dave and I. So we have different personalities and different approaches to things, but I think the general strategy will remain consistent, and that is to focus clearly on increasing shareholder value. Ultimately, a lot of that comes from driving costs lower. And I think we -- you've heard us talk about it, but 2 big themes here are consolidation and innovation. So we've talked a lot about longer laterals and the economic benefits we get from that. And over the past 8 years or so with the Marcellus, you've seen the progress us and the industry has made on improving returns through innovation and new technologies, and we will continue to try and be a leader in that area. So I think there's always been a strong operational focus as well as a strong financial focus. You will see that continue, although I think there will probably be less financial engineering that will be needed in the future than we've seen over the past 7 years or so.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: So I guess, as you try might [ph] be focusing on -- partly on cost and lateral lengths, how much of extending laterals you think you can do from really locking up and acreage swaps versus needing to really consolidate land position through acquisitions?
componenttext: So I guess, as you try might [ph] be focusing on -- partly on cost and lateral lengths, how much of extending laterals you think you can do from really locking up and acreage swaps versus needing to really consolidate land position through acquisitions?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's going to require both. But I think to get meaningful improvement is clearly going to require some additional acquisition opportunities. We've seen significant benefits from the ones we've done. And that's the kind of thing that builds o
componenttext: Well, I think it's going to require both. But I think to get meaningful improvement is clearly going to require some additional acquisition opportunities. We've seen significant benefits from the ones we've done. And that's the kind of thing that builds on itself. So the more you do, the more benefits you get even from the previous acquisitions. And that said, the bigger position we build in the core area certainly facilitates additional trades with our partners. We're also trying to consolidate their positions because they see the value as well. So you're going to see both, and I think we'd like to continue to do some acquisition activity. As I mentioned, we think the smaller deals, like we've done, are much more likely than any sort of large strategic merging of big players.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Last one for me, Steve. You guys will have a bigger program in the Upper Devonian this year than, I guess, last year in particular. Do you feel like you'll likely learn a lot more about how to develop those 2 concurrently? Or does it -- you feel like you
componenttext: Last one for me, Steve. You guys will have a bigger program in the Upper Devonian this year than, I guess, last year in particular. Do you feel like you'll likely learn a lot more about how to develop those 2 concurrently? Or does it -- you feel like you already know plenty about the reservoir and incremental earnings will be small?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: I think we have a pretty good understanding. I think we have more producing Upper Devonian wells than anyone else. And we feel strongly in the data that's coming in, is confirming our belief that within that certain area that we show in our investor prese
componenttext: I think we have a pretty good understanding. I think we have more producing Upper Devonian wells than anyone else. And we feel strongly in the data that's coming in, is confirming our belief that within that certain area that we show in our investor presentation. Within that area, it is a use it or lose it proposition. And incrementally, the MPV per acre is significantly higher if we take the Upper Devonian now in conjunction with the Marcellus than if we don't and then lose the opportunity forever. So we feel even more certain about that conclusion today than we did even 6 months ago. But I think because of the number of wells we have producing, I think we have a high level of certainty about the results and what the right approach is in that area.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Hanold with RBC.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Hanold with RBC.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: So Steve, I like that -- I like the consolidation and innovation theme. It's pretty catching and pretty applicable to you all. Can you talk a little bit more on the innovation side of things? Where can you go from here? I mean, obviously, longer laterals
componenttext: So Steve, I like that -- I like the consolidation and innovation theme. It's pretty catching and pretty applicable to you all. Can you talk a little bit more on the innovation side of things? Where can you go from here? I mean, obviously, longer laterals are sort of the, I guess, I'll say the layup. But when you look at just in sort of the proppant loading, stage spacing, where do you think you could go from where we're at today?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, I think on the -- like on the completion side, as we mentioned before, we started doing bigger frac jobs and higher proppant loadings. We're not quite ready to announce any revisions to our type curves, but I would expect that we'll have an update b
componenttext: Well, I think on the -- like on the completion side, as we mentioned before, we started doing bigger frac jobs and higher proppant loadings. We're not quite ready to announce any revisions to our type curves, but I would expect that we'll have an update by the next call. We just want to get a little more data there. And we're expanding that to -- we're now testing even higher proppant loads. That will take some more time to conclude how much or if there's a benefit there, but we continue to experiment and look for better ways on the completion side. I would say our innovations are solely focused on drilling and completion activities, though. And a couple of areas that we're doing a lot of work in are kind of more on the logistical side. So we're doing a lot of operations research kind of work on our rig scheduling and our frac scheduling and how we move and transport water. And what we're finding through some pretty advanced modeling is our previous assumptions about what was optimum turn out to be pretty far off. And the conclusions from these models really aren't intuitive. Very difficult for a human being to look at spreadsheet and come up with the optimum schedule. So we're just starting that kind of work. We think the applicability to our business could be pretty widespread and potentially pretty dramatic in terms of lowering our unit operating cost. So a lot of work happening in that area. It'll take some time, but we're pretty excited about it.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Can you give us an example of what you mean by that, just some of the logistical things, I mean, maybe just one fill in example just to give us some construct of what you all are doing in the theme?
componenttext: Can you give us an example of what you mean by that, just some of the logistical things, I mean, maybe just one fill in example just to give us some construct of what you all are doing in the theme?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure. So one example we did is, we brought in a Ph.D. from Carnegie Mellon University to help us with this modeling because it's pretty advanced stuff for, certainly for someone like me. And the first thing he did is he did a look back on a group of pads
componenttext: Sure. So one example we did is, we brought in a Ph.D. from Carnegie Mellon University to help us with this modeling because it's pretty advanced stuff for, certainly for someone like me. And the first thing he did is he did a look back on a group of pads in Greene County that we already drilled. So we had -- we knew what that was optimal. And our typical assumption was generally, if we have multi-well pads drill all the wells with a rig. It's very expensive to move rigs, about $0.5 million every time we move a rig, so we thought it was best to drill all the wells, move the rig somewhere else, bring in the frac crews, bring in the water and the sand, and frac all the wells back-to-back, and then bring them all online. And if you look back and build this model, which incorporated the logistics of the water, logistics of the crews, the downtime associated with the production, the pipeline capacities and capacity availability and a number of other variables, and the rig schedule that printed out look like a pig's breakfast. I mean, it was moving rigs a lot more often than we thought but said that we would've created significantly more value have we followed to that schedule. So that really opened our eyes, and we really thought this might really add some value at this look at this kind of results everywhere else. So we're starting to apply that, again, to rig and frac scheduling but also just helping us decide how to better design our pipeline systems to make that capital more efficient. And importantly, the best ways to move our water because that's becoming a bigger and bigger piece of our cost structure.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: That was really helpful. And for a follow-up question, on the consolidation side of things, it sounded like you did a acquisition here recently. And I'm sorry if I missed it, did you say what the production volume at from there was. If you have that, that
componenttext: That was really helpful. And for a follow-up question, on the consolidation side of things, it sounded like you did a acquisition here recently. And I'm sorry if I missed it, did you say what the production volume at from there was. If you have that, that'd be great. But just big picture, how many of these, outside of like just regular freighting, how many of these little bolt-on opportunities are still hanging out there in your core area?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, on your first question, it didn't have any. Current production was strictly undeveloped acreage. And I will mention on it just because it makes us want to be unique is all of that acreage is either fee, about 1/2 of it is in fee, so 100% net revenue
componenttext: Well, on your first question, it didn't have any. Current production was strictly undeveloped acreage. And I will mention on it just because it makes us want to be unique is all of that acreage is either fee, about 1/2 of it is in fee, so 100% net revenue interest, and the other half is held by production by shallow wells. So we control that acreage forever and have a very high net revenue interest. Regarding how many others are out there, it's always hard to say because they're always -- there's been for the past years a fairly steady flow of opportunities, and we've been involved in all our most of those. And I think we're still optimistic that, that flow is going to continue. But it's hard to predict. At any given time, there's 2 or 3 that are, I'd say, active. But sometimes, active means there's a day room and the sellers clearly motivated to sell. And other times active means we're in discussions with a party and it seems like there might be a deal to be done, but sometimes it doesn't work out so. I would say for the scale of acquisitions we've been doing, we expect to float and continue for at least a while.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2017

Is that just 2 months now of better [indiscernible] pricing? Or if you've got some sort of fundamental change that you're seeing good flow-through for the rest of '17?

componenttext: Holly, this is Rob. It really just reflects what the market pricing is. We're just taking the forward curve at the different places where we sell our gas, so we're not taking a view that's different in the market. It's just that the forward curve has improved on basis.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then maybe, Steve, I know you mentioned MVP, maybe just some thoughts there. It looks like we should receive a final EIS maybe in mid-March. So just given kind of what's going on with the commission right now, just any sort of thoughts th
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then maybe, Steve, I know you mentioned MVP, maybe just some thoughts there. It looks like we should receive a final EIS maybe in mid-March. So just given kind of what's going on with the commission right now, just any sort of thoughts there on how to that thing could play out for MVP?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, Holly, well, first of all, the final EIS is not dependent on having a quorum on the commission, so the staff can take care of that. So we think as far as the current situation with the commissioners shouldn't have any impact on our receipt o
componenttext: Yes. I think, Holly, well, first of all, the final EIS is not dependent on having a quorum on the commission, so the staff can take care of that. So we think as far as the current situation with the commissioners shouldn't have any impact on our receipt of the final environmental impact statement. We are responding to a long list of questions, which seems to be the norm in today's environment. And we continue to hope to get it on time. I think we understand that there's a possibility that the FBIS could be delayed. I say we still have some slack in the schedule, and the real target date for us is to receive the notice to proceed in November. So I think we're still, still optimistic that we're on schedule and we'll be able to get this thing online by the end of 2018. Probably the last thing I would say is a lot of the work we're doing in responding to the questions we think will go a long way toward answering a lot of the questions and help with a lot of the work that the other agencies have to do once we receive the FBIS. So even if we could debate on the FBIS, it doesn't necessarily mean that the entire process is delayed.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's great. And then one final one for me. On the 7 [ph] Utica test for 2017, can you give us the PA West Virginia split?
componenttext: Okay, that's great. And then one final one for me. On the 7 [ph] Utica test for 2017, can you give us the PA West Virginia split?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say right now we don't know. We're going to keep that open depending on results. Right now, from what we're seeing, I would imagine the majority will be in Pennsylvania. But as I said, we're currently fracking a well in West Virginia. And if
componenttext: Well, I would say right now we don't know. We're going to keep that open depending on results. Right now, from what we're seeing, I would imagine the majority will be in Pennsylvania. But as I said, we're currently fracking a well in West Virginia. And if that result is encouraging, we might shift a few of them to West Virginia. So we're going to be driven by the results we see.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: On the topic of longer laterals, without additional acquisitions, where could you get to on the company average basis a couple of years out versus where you are today? And if we think about the acquisition opportunity, is there some way of summarizing whe
componenttext: On the topic of longer laterals, without additional acquisitions, where could you get to on the company average basis a couple of years out versus where you are today? And if we think about the acquisition opportunity, is there some way of summarizing where you could say for x million dollars of acquisitions, you could take that company average lateral length out to some fill in the blank kind of number?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Those are pretty impossible questions to answer. What I can tell you is we're looking out 2018, we expect the average to be 8,000 feet or above. So we continue to increase that average length pretty significantly year-over-year. It's hard to predict with
componenttext: Those are pretty impossible questions to answer. What I can tell you is we're looking out 2018, we expect the average to be 8,000 feet or above. So we continue to increase that average length pretty significantly year-over-year. It's hard to predict with additional acquisitions what the impacts will be because it's very dependent on where they're at. Also dependent on other activity, leasing activity, where that is, how contiguous those pieces are, so very tough to answer that. I will say in theory, we think 15,000-foot laterals are optimum. I don't expect that we will get there, so I'd be clear on that. But any additional length up to something close to that adds real value to our investment. So we're going to continue to do everything we can to get them as long as we can.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Just one additional comment to that. I would say that we clearly have [indiscernible] if we're doing an acquisition that it is helping us with lateral lengths. If it's not, it's not an acquisition that we'd likely do. It's hard to quantify how much that w

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we run most of our economics at the local price. So if it doesn't make sense to that, we're not going to be reinvesting. And I think we've laid out on our investor presentations where our market mix is, and so that should keep your pretty cl
componenttext: Well, I think we run most of our economics at the local price. So if it doesn't make sense to that, we're not going to be reinvesting. And I think we've laid out on our investor presentations where our market mix is, and so that should keep your pretty clear idea of -- and it's all pretty fungible because of the other system on the Equitrans system. All that's connected, so we can move gas it all those markets pretty easily. And the next big shift you will see beyond that the recent OBC and Rex capacity, the next date will be with MVP becomes operational and we're sending a lot of gas to the southeast market.

componenttext: Well, I think when it's all is said and done, that's probably not likely to be the case. headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think I'm going to pass on that for now. I think we want together a little bit more data before we start quoting our uplift estimates. I will stay from the results we're seeing, they seem pretty consistent with our modeling suggested we'd see, so w
componenttext: Yes, I think I'm going to pass on that for now. I think we want together a little bit more data before we start quoting our uplift estimates. I will stay from the results we're seeing, they seem pretty consistent with our modeling suggested we'd see, so we're optimistic that it's working. But we don't quite have enough data to want to commit to any numbers, so I'd ask you to hold off until the next call where we would expect to be able to quote something that we can stand behind.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just last question regarding MVP. It sounds like you guys are still confident in the timing, but if there are some timing slippage, how could that affect the company? And what are some thoughts around, managing around that timing risk?
componenttext: Okay. And just last question regarding MVP. It sounds like you guys are still confident in the timing, but if there are some timing slippage, how could that affect the company? And what are some thoughts around, managing around that timing risk?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: I think the nature of the construction process is the critical path on the MVP project is around the compressor station construction, about 14 months time frame to do that. So because of the nature of that, a 1-month delay in getting approval is probably
componenttext: I think the nature of the construction process is the critical path on the MVP project is around the compressor station construction, about 14 months time frame to do that. So because of the nature of that, a 1-month delay in getting approval is probably a 1-month delay in turning line. The next item on the critical path is actual construction of the line, which is dependent on our ability to be able to clear trees. And there are limits around because of the bad populations when we're able to do that. So generally speaking, and there are lots of variables, so none of this is for certain, but delaying the notice to proceed at least on that part of it is possible to get the partial notice to proceed on the compressor station. But pipeline construction delayed in the February, it might get difficult to get the trees cleared and the tree clearing window to hold to that end of 2018 time frame. So those are kind of some of the key dates we're focused on. But that said, there are possible mitigants to that in terms of, again, partial notices to proceed or possibilities of being able to extend the tree cutting window. So lots of variables, but those are some key dates we're shooting for.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: I would say we don't have any particular focus areas. We look at the opportunities that come up and see how well they fit. And some of those on the eastern side and the dry area fit very, very well, so we get a lot of the synergy value, which is what we'r
componenttext: I would say we don't have any particular focus areas. We look at the opportunities that come up and see how well they fit. And some of those on the eastern side and the dry area fit very, very well, so we get a lot of the synergy value, which is what we're looking for. But as always, they have to make sense. So we're not going to go buy acreage in areas where we're not confident we can earn good returns on our drilling investments. So again, we've been pretty encouraged with the results we're seeing in those areas, so I think we feel really good about them. And they've been a particularly nice fit with our existing position.

componenttext: We certainly think it could have impact on that. And if it does, the impact is almost certainly to shorten those cycle times. We weren't ready yet to haven't done enough of the work yet to really build in any benefit in 2017, not to say we won't see any, we might. But I would think we'll have enough of the modeling done and tested enough hopefully by 2018 to incorporate it into our planning.

componenttext: Okay. And then just one last one I had was, we've certainly seen a nice uptick in NGL prices. Is that -- I know people -- you can kind of talked about, Steve, on the call so far, were you thinking about drilling with all the rigs, you certainly going to be active. Does improvement of NGL prices change how you think about target areas? I mean, when I look particularly on the Marcellus, you've got that rectangle always laid out where you're looking at new and existing acreage. Does the improvement of NGL prices change where you might target some of the drilling to latter part of this year?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't think the changes in NGL prices so far have been dramatic enough to have us rethink where we think we're going to be drilling. And there's always a number of factors that go into how we develop our plan. Certainly, prices are a big factor, b
componenttext: Well, I don't think the changes in NGL prices so far have been dramatic enough to have us rethink where we think we're going to be drilling. And there's always a number of factors that go into how we develop our plan. Certainly, prices are a big factor, but available capacity where the gathering systems have capacity to market, where we have processing capacity and we -- at least, personally, I'm always reluctant to make short-term changes in our plans based on short-term changes in commodity prices, especially given that the 9- to 12-month delay from when we change our plans to when we're getting the production online. It just seems like every time we try and do that, we're never in sync with the market. We're always chasing the market, and it's changed by the time we benefit from it. So the moves would have to be dramatic, and we have to have the view that they're going to be sustained before we would really work, rework calendar year development plan.

componenttext: I think for the areas we're likely to test, we have plenty of takeaway for 7 wells. So I think the takeaway question really isn't going to factor into where we're drilling. These tests are still mostly designed to understand the reservoir. Again, I think on the cost side, we're really happy with where we're at. But we want to understand what the production mechanisms, what the recoveries are going to be and what's the extent of the economic area of the Utica. So that's what's going to drive our location decisions in 2017.
